statement: There is no evidence for a seasonal shift in the host use pattern in Cx. quinquefasciatus populations from the southern latitudes, raising questions about whether the Argentinian population is appropriate for testing the seasonal host switching hypothesis.

There is no replication built into the experimental design, which is problematic since egg lay is a highly variable trait even within treatments and it is standard practice to replicate mosquito fitness experiments.
The sample size is particularly small for some groups (e.g. 15 egg rafts for the second gonotrophic cycle of mice in the autumn), which limits the statistical power to detect treatment effects.
Cx. quinquefasciatus host switching has not been observed in Argentina, only in the northern hemisphere, so it is possible that the species could have an entirely different ecology in Argentina.

It would have been helpful to conduct a blood meal analysis prior to this experiment to determine whether using an Argentinian population was appropriate to assess the seasonal host switching question.

The impacts of certain experimental design decisions are not acknowledged in the research plan, such as how rearing larvae under the same conditions prevents mechanisms of action that could occur as a result of seasonality experienced by mothers, eggs, and larvae.
